slides.title: Introduction to Interest
slides.content:
Interest is money paid for the use of borrowed money. It's a crucial topic in SSC GD with 2-3 questions typically appearing in the exam.

What is Interest?
When you borrow money from someone (bank, person, institution), you pay extra money for using it. This extra money is called Interest.

When you lend money or deposit in bank, you receive interest.
When you borrow money or take a loan, you pay interest.

Basic Terms:

1. Principal (P):
   The original amount borrowed or invested.
   Also called: Capital, Sum
   
   Example: If you borrow â‚¹10,000, then P = â‚¹10,000

2. Rate of Interest (R):
   The percentage charged on the principal per year.
   Usually expressed as % per annum (p.a.)
   
   Example: If rate is 10%, then R = 10% p.a.

3. Time (T):
   The duration for which money is borrowed/invested.
   Usually expressed in years.
   
   For months: Time (in years) = Months/12
   For days: Time (in years) = Days/365
   
   Example: 6 months = 6/12 = 0.5 years
            73 days = 73/365 = 0.2 years

4. Interest (I or SI/CI):
   The extra money paid or received.
   
   Example: If you borrow â‚¹10,000 and pay back â‚¹11,000
            Interest = â‚¹1,000

5. Amount (A):
   The total money paid back or received.
   Amount = Principal + Interest
   
   Example: P = â‚¹10,000, Interest = â‚¹1,000
            Amount = â‚¹11,000

Types of Interest:

1. Simple Interest (SI):
   Interest calculated only on the principal amount.
   Remains constant throughout the period.
   Easier to calculate.
   Used in: Short-term loans, simple deposits

2. Compound Interest (CI):
   Interest calculated on principal + accumulated interest.
   Interest changes (increases) every period.
   More realistic for long-term investments.
   Used in: Bank deposits, long-term loans, investments

Example Comparison:

Principal = â‚¹1000, Rate = 10% p.a., Time = 3 years

Simple Interest:
Year 1: Interest = 10% of 1000 = â‚¹100
Year 2: Interest = 10% of 1000 = â‚¹100
Year 3: Interest = 10% of 1000 = â‚¹100
Total SI = â‚¹300
Amount = â‚¹1300

Compound Interest:
Year 1: Interest = 10% of 1000 = â‚¹100, Amount = â‚¹1100
Year 2: Interest = 10% of 1100 = â‚¹110, Amount = â‚¹1210
Year 3: Interest = 10% of 1210 = â‚¹121, Amount = â‚¹1331
Total CI = â‚¹331
Amount = â‚¹1331

Notice: CI > SI (Compound Interest is always more than Simple Interest for same P, R, T)

Why Study Interest?

1. Practical Application:
   - Bank deposits and savings
   - Loans (home, car, personal)
   - Credit cards
   - Investments
   - Daily financial decisions

2. Exam Importance:
   - 2-3 questions in SSC GD
   - Easy scoring if formulas clear
   - Direct formula application
   - Moderate difficulty

3. Life Skill:
   - Understand loan EMI
   - Compare investment options
   - Make informed financial decisions

Key Points:

- Interest is always calculated on some amount
- Rate is usually per year (per annum)
- Time must be in years for standard formulas
- Amount = Principal + Interest
- SI is calculated on original principal only
- CI is calculated on growing amount
- CI > SI (for same P, R, T when T > 1)
- For T = 1 year, SI = CI

Common Notation:

P = Principal
R = Rate of interest (% per annum)
T = Time (in years)
SI = Simple Interest
CI = Compound Interest
A = Amount

Basic Relationships:

1. Amount = Principal + Interest
   A = P + I

2. Interest = Amount - Principal
   I = A - P

3. Principal = Amount - Interest
   P = A - I

Exam Strategy:

- Identify if it's SI or CI problem
- Note down P, R, T clearly
- Choose appropriate formula
- Calculate step by step
- Verify answer makes sense

Remember:
- Simple Interest: Straight line growth
- Compound Interest: Exponential growth
- Always CI â‰¥ SI

Now let's dive deep into Simple Interest first, then Compound Interest!

slides.title: Simple Interest - Basics and Formula
slides.content:
Simple Interest (SI) is interest calculated only on the principal amount throughout the loan/investment period.

Simple Interest Formula:

SI = (P Ã— R Ã— T) / 100

Where:
P = Principal (original amount)
R = Rate of interest (% per annum)
T = Time (in years)

Alternatively written as:
SI = PRT/100

Derivation Logic:

If R% per year means:
- On â‚¹100, you get â‚¹R per year
- On â‚¹P, you get (P Ã— R)/100 per year
- For T years, you get (P Ã— R Ã— T)/100

Amount Formula:

Amount = Principal + Simple Interest
A = P + SI
A = P + (PRT/100)
A = P(1 + RT/100)

Example 1: Basic Calculation
Find SI on â‚¹5000 at 10% p.a. for 3 years.

Solution:
P = â‚¹5000
R = 10% p.a.
T = 3 years

SI = (P Ã— R Ã— T)/100
   = (5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 3)/100
   = 150000/100
   = â‚¹1500

Amount = P + SI
       = 5000 + 1500
       = â‚¹6500

Example 2: Time in Months
Find SI on â‚¹8000 at 12% p.a. for 9 months.

Solution:
P = â‚¹8000
R = 12% p.a.
T = 9 months = 9/12 years = 3/4 years = 0.75 years

SI = (8000 Ã— 12 Ã— 0.75)/100
   = 72000/100
   = â‚¹720

Example 3: Time in Days
Find SI on â‚¹10,000 at 15% p.a. for 73 days.

Solution:
P = â‚¹10,000
R = 15% p.a.
T = 73 days = 73/365 years = 0.2 years

SI = (10000 Ã— 15 Ã— 0.2)/100
   = 30000/100
   = â‚¹300

Finding Principal (P):

From SI = PRT/100
P = (SI Ã— 100)/(R Ã— T)

Example: SI is â‚¹600, rate is 10% p.a., time is 3 years. Find P.

P = (600 Ã— 100)/(10 Ã— 3)
  = 60000/30
  = â‚¹2000

Finding Rate (R):

R = (SI Ã— 100)/(P Ã— T)

Example: P = â‚¹4000, SI = â‚¹800, T = 4 years. Find R.

R = (800 Ã— 100)/(4000 Ã— 4)
  = 80000/16000
  = 5% p.a.

Finding Time (T):

T = (SI Ã— 100)/(P Ã— R)

Example: P = â‚¹5000, SI = â‚¹1000, R = 10% p.a. Find T.

T = (1000 Ã— 100)/(5000 Ã— 10)
  = 100000/50000
  = 2 years

Finding Amount (A):

A = P + SI
Or directly:
A = P(1 + RT/100)

Example: P = â‚¹6000, R = 8% p.a., T = 2 years. Find Amount.

Method 1:
SI = (6000 Ã— 8 Ã— 2)/100 = 960
A = 6000 + 960 = â‚¹6960

Method 2:
A = 6000(1 + (8Ã—2)/100)
  = 6000(1 + 16/100)
  = 6000(1 + 0.16)
  = 6000 Ã— 1.16
  = â‚¹6960

Finding Principal from Amount:

P = A/(1 + RT/100)

Or:
P = (A Ã— 100)/(100 + RT)

Example: Amount is â‚¹6600, R = 10%, T = 2 years. Find P.

P = 6600/(1 + (10Ã—2)/100)
  = 6600/(1 + 0.2)
  = 6600/1.2
  = â‚¹5500

Verification:
SI = (5500 Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = 1100
A = 5500 + 1100 = 6600 âœ“

Multiple Principals:

Example: â‚¹x at 10% for 2 years and â‚¹y at 12% for 3 years give total SI of â‚¹1500. If x = 2000, find y.

Solution:
SIâ‚ = (2000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = 400
SIâ‚‚ = (y Ã— 12 Ã— 3)/100 = 0.36y

Total: 400 + 0.36y = 1500
0.36y = 1100
y = 1100/0.36 = â‚¹3055.56

Unequal Time Periods:

Example: â‚¹5000 at 10% p.a. for 2 years, then rate changes to 12% for next 3 years. Find total SI.

Solution:
SI for first 2 years = (5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = â‚¹1000
SI for next 3 years = (5000 Ã— 12 Ã— 3)/100 = â‚¹1800
Total SI = 1000 + 1800 = â‚¹2800

Note: In SI, principal remains same always!

Quick Mental Calculations:

1. If R Ã— T = 100:
   SI = P (same as principal)
   
   Example: P = 5000, R = 20%, T = 5 years
   R Ã— T = 100, so SI = â‚¹5000

2. If R = 10%, T = 1 year:
   SI = P/10
   
   Example: P = 3000
   SI = 3000/10 = â‚¹300

3. For doubling (A = 2P):
   SI = P, so (P Ã— R Ã— T)/100 = P
   Therefore: R Ã— T = 100
   
   Example: At 5% p.a., time to double = 100/5 = 20 years

Common Mistakes:

1. Forgetting to convert time to years
2. Using wrong formula
3. Calculation errors
4. Not converting rate to decimal when needed
5. Confusing SI with CI

Exam Tips:

- Write P, R, T clearly
- Convert time to years if needed
- Use SI = PRT/100 formula
- Calculate step by step
- Verify: SI should be positive and reasonable
- Amount should be greater than Principal

slides.title: Simple Interest - Advanced Problems
slides.content:
Let's explore more complex Simple Interest problems that frequently appear in SSC GD.

Ratio of Principal and SI:

Example 1: Principal and SI are in ratio 5:2. If rate is 10% p.a., find time.

Solution:
Let P = 5x and SI = 2x

SI = PRT/100
2x = (5x Ã— 10 Ã— T)/100
2x = 5xT/10
2x = xT/2
2 = T/2
T = 4 years

Example 2: SI for 4 years is 2/5 of principal. Find rate.

Solution:
SI = (2/5)P
T = 4 years

SI = PRT/100
(2/5)P = (P Ã— R Ã— 4)/100
2/5 = 4R/100
2/5 = R/25
R = (2 Ã— 25)/5 = 10% p.a.

Difference in SI for Different Times:

Example: Difference between SI for 5 years and 3 years is â‚¹400. If rate is 10% p.a., find principal.

Solution:
SI for 5 years = (P Ã— 10 Ã— 5)/100 = 0.5P
SI for 3 years = (P Ã— 10 Ã— 3)/100 = 0.3P

Difference = 0.5P - 0.3P = 0.2P

Given: 0.2P = 400
P = 400/0.2 = â‚¹2000

Difference in SI for Different Rates:

Example: Difference in SI at 12% and 10% for 2 years on same principal is â‚¹200. Find principal.

Solution:
SI at 12% = (P Ã— 12 Ã— 2)/100 = 0.24P
SI at 10% = (P Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = 0.20P

Difference = 0.24P - 0.20P = 0.04P

Given: 0.04P = 200
P = 200/0.04 = â‚¹5000

Equal SI from Two Principals:

Example: â‚¹x at 10% for 3 years gives same SI as â‚¹(x+1000) at 8% for 2 years. Find x.

Solution:
SIâ‚ = (x Ã— 10 Ã— 3)/100 = 0.3x
SIâ‚‚ = [(x+1000) Ã— 8 Ã— 2]/100 = 0.16(x+1000)

Equal SI:
0.3x = 0.16x + 160
0.14x = 160
x = 160/0.14 = â‚¹1142.86

Sum and Difference Problems:

Example: Sum of principal and SI is â‚¹1400. If R = 10%, T = 4 years, find P.

Solution:
P + SI = 1400
SI = PRT/100 = (P Ã— 10 Ã— 4)/100 = 0.4P

P + 0.4P = 1400
1.4P = 1400
P = 1400/1.4 = â‚¹1000

Verification:
SI = 1000 Ã— 0.4 = 400
P + SI = 1000 + 400 = 1400 âœ“

Time Period Problems:

Example: A sum becomes double itself in 10 years at SI. In how many years will it become triple?

Solution:
For doubling:
A = 2P, so SI = P
SI = PRT/100
P = (P Ã— R Ã— 10)/100
1 = R/10
R = 10% p.a.

For tripling:
A = 3P, so SI = 2P
2P = (P Ã— 10 Ã— T)/100
2 = T/10
T = 20 years

Pattern: Time to become n times = (n-1) Ã— Time to double

Variable Rate Problems:

Example: â‚¹5000 invested at 8% for first year, 10% for second year, 12% for third year. Find total SI.

Solution:
SI Year 1 = (5000 Ã— 8 Ã— 1)/100 = 400
SI Year 2 = (5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 1)/100 = 500
SI Year 3 = (5000 Ã— 12 Ã— 1)/100 = 600

Total SI = 400 + 500 + 600 = â‚¹1500

Alternatively:
Average rate = (8 + 10 + 12)/3 = 10% p.a.
SI = (5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 3)/100 = â‚¹1500

True Discount and Banker's Discount:

(These are advanced topics, usually not in SSC GD, but good to know)

True Discount: SI on Present Worth
Banker's Discount: SI on Face Value

Partial Payment Problems:

Example: â‚¹10,000 borrowed at 10% p.a. After 1 year, â‚¹5000 paid. What is due after 2 years from start?

Solution:
After 1 year:
SI = (10000 Ã— 10 Ã— 1)/100 = 1000
Amount = 10000 + 1000 = 11000
Paid = 5000
Remaining = 6000

For next 1 year on â‚¹6000:
SI = (6000 Ã— 10 Ã— 1)/100 = 600
Amount due = 6000 + 600 = â‚¹6600

Comparison Problems:

Example: At what rate will â‚¹4000 amount to â‚¹5000 in 5 years at SI?

Solution:
P = 4000, A = 5000, T = 5 years
SI = A - P = 5000 - 4000 = 1000

SI = PRT/100
1000 = (4000 Ã— R Ã— 5)/100
1000 = 200R
R = 5% p.a.

Investment Split:

Example: â‚¹12,000 divided into two parts such that SI on first part at 10% for 3 years equals SI on second part at 12% for 2.5 years. Find the parts.

Solution:
Let first part = x, second part = (12000 - x)

SIâ‚ = (x Ã— 10 Ã— 3)/100 = 0.3x
SIâ‚‚ = [(12000-x) Ã— 12 Ã— 2.5]/100 = 0.3(12000-x)

Equal SI:
0.3x = 0.3(12000 - x)
x = 12000 - x
2x = 12000
x = â‚¹6000

Parts: â‚¹6000 and â‚¹6000

Loan Repayment:

Example: â‚¹5000 loan at 8% p.a. to be repaid in 2 equal yearly installments. Find installment amount.

Solution:
Let each installment = x

Present value of both installments = 5000

First installment (paid after 1 year):
PV = x/(1 + 0.08Ã—1) = x/1.08

Second installment (paid after 2 years):
PV = x/(1 + 0.08Ã—2) = x/1.16

Total: x/1.08 + x/1.16 = 5000

Solving:
1.16x + 1.08x = 5000 Ã— 1.08 Ã— 1.16
2.24x = 6264
x = â‚¹2796.43

(This is approximate method for SI; exact method uses different formula)

Exam Strategy:

- Identify what is asked
- Note down given values
- Choose appropriate approach
- Set up equation if needed
- Solve systematically
- Verify answer

slides.title: Compound Interest - Basics
slides.content:
Compound Interest is interest calculated on principal plus previously earned interest. It's called 'interest on interest'.

What is Compounding?

In CI, interest earned in each period is added to the principal for next period's calculation.

Example:
P = â‚¹1000, R = 10% p.a., T = 3 years

Year 1:
Interest = 10% of 1000 = â‚¹100
Amount = 1000 + 100 = â‚¹1100

Year 2:
Interest = 10% of 1100 = â‚¹110 (not on 1000!)
Amount = 1100 + 110 = â‚¹1210

Year 3:
Interest = 10% of 1210 = â‚¹121
Amount = 1210 + 121 = â‚¹1331

Total CI = 1331 - 1000 = â‚¹331

Compound Interest Formula:

Amount after n years:
A = P(1 + R/100)^n

Where:
P = Principal
R = Rate of interest per period
n = Number of periods (years)

Compound Interest:
CI = A - P
CI = P(1 + R/100)^n - P
CI = P[(1 + R/100)^n - 1]

Example 1: Find CI on â‚¹5000 at 10% p.a. for 2 years.

Solution:
P = 5000, R = 10%, n = 2

A = 5000(1 + 10/100)Â²
  = 5000(1.1)Â²
  = 5000 Ã— 1.21
  = â‚¹6050

CI = A - P = 6050 - 5000 = â‚¹1050

Verification (year by year):
Year 1: SI = 500, Amount = 5500
Year 2: Interest on 5500 = 550, Amount = 6050
CI = 1050 âœ“

Example 2: Find CI on â‚¹8000 at 15% p.a. for 3 years.

Solution:
A = 8000(1 + 15/100)Â³
  = 8000(1.15)Â³
  = 8000 Ã— 1.520875
  = â‚¹12,167

CI = 12167 - 8000 = â‚¹4167

Compounding Periods:

1. Annually: Interest added once per year
   A = P(1 + R/100)^n

2. Semi-annually (Half-yearly): Interest added twice per year
   A = P(1 + R/200)^(2n)
   (Rate becomes R/2, time becomes 2n)

3. Quarterly: Interest added 4 times per year
   A = P(1 + R/400)^(4n)
   (Rate becomes R/4, time becomes 4n)

4. Monthly: Interest added 12 times per year
   A = P(1 + R/1200)^(12n)
   (Rate becomes R/12, time becomes 12n)

Example: Semi-annual Compounding
P = â‚¹10,000, R = 20% p.a., T = 1 year, compounded half-yearly

Solution:
Since half-yearly:
Rate per half-year = 20/2 = 10%
Number of half-years = 1 Ã— 2 = 2

A = 10000(1 + 10/100)Â²
  = 10000(1.1)Â²
  = 10000 Ã— 1.21
  = â‚¹12,100

CI = 12100 - 10000 = â‚¹2100

Compare with annual:
A = 10000(1 + 20/100)Â¹ = 12000
CI = 2000

Note: More frequent compounding â†’ Higher CI

Example: Quarterly Compounding
P = â‚¹8000, R = 16% p.a., T = 6 months, compounded quarterly

Solution:
Rate per quarter = 16/4 = 4%
Number of quarters = 0.5 Ã— 4 = 2

A = 8000(1 + 4/100)Â²
  = 8000(1.04)Â²
  = 8000 Ã— 1.0816
  = â‚¹8652.8

CI = 8652.8 - 8000 = â‚¹652.8

When Time is Not Whole Number:

Example: CI for 2 years 6 months

Method 1: Convert to years
T = 2.5 years
A = P(1 + R/100)^2.5

Method 2: Separate calculation
For 2 years: A = P(1 + R/100)Â²
For 6 months: SI on this amount
Total = A + SI

Example: P = â‚¹10,000, R = 10%, T = 2 years 3 months

Method 2 (easier for non-calculators):
For 2 years:
A = 10000(1.1)Â² = 10000 Ã— 1.21 = â‚¹12,100

For 3 months = 0.25 years:
SI = (12100 Ã— 10 Ã— 0.25)/100 = â‚¹302.5

Final Amount = 12100 + 302.5 = â‚¹12,402.5
CI = 12402.5 - 10000 = â‚¹2402.5

Difference Between CI and SI:

For same P, R, T:
CI - SI = ?

For 2 years:
SI = (P Ã— R Ã— 2)/100 = 2PR/100
CI = P[(1 + R/100)Â² - 1]
   = P[1 + 2R/100 + RÂ²/10000 - 1]
   = P[2R/100 + RÂ²/10000]

Difference = CI - SI
           = P[2R/100 + RÂ²/10000] - 2PR/100
           = PRÂ²/10000
           = P(R/100)Â²

Formula for 2 years:
CI - SI = P(R/100)Â²

Example: P = â‚¹10,000, R = 10%, T = 2 years
CI - SI = 10000(10/100)Â²
        = 10000 Ã— 0.01
        = â‚¹100

Verification:
SI = (10000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = 2000
CI = 10000[(1.1)Â² - 1] = 10000 Ã— 0.21 = 2100
Difference = 2100 - 2000 = 100 âœ“

For 3 years:
CI - SI = [PRÂ²(300 + R)]/1000000

Using Powers:

Common powers to remember:
1.1Â² = 1.21
1.1Â³ = 1.331
1.1â´ = 1.4641
1.05Â² = 1.1025
1.05Â³ = 1.157625
1.2Â² = 1.44
1.2Â³ = 1.728

These help in quick calculations!

Exam Tips:

- Use A = P(1 + R/100)^n formula
- For fractional years, use method 2
- Remember common powers
- For compounding periods, adjust R and n
- CI = Amount - Principal
- Always CI â‰¥ SI

slides.title: Compound Interest - Advanced Problems
slides.content:
Let's explore advanced CI problems commonly asked in SSC GD exams.

Finding Principal from Amount:

A = P(1 + R/100)^n
P = A/(1 + R/100)^n

Example: Amount after 2 years at 10% CI is â‚¹12,100. Find principal.

P = 12100/(1.1)Â²
  = 12100/1.21
  = â‚¹10,000

Finding Rate:

A = P(1 + R/100)^n
(1 + R/100)^n = A/P

For 2 years:
(1 + R/100)Â² = A/P
1 + R/100 = âˆš(A/P)
R/100 = âˆš(A/P) - 1
R = [âˆš(A/P) - 1] Ã— 100

Example: â‚¹10,000 becomes â‚¹12,100 in 2 years at CI. Find rate.

A/P = 12100/10000 = 1.21
âˆš1.21 = 1.1
R = (1.1 - 1) Ã— 100 = 10% p.a.

Finding Time:

A = P(1 + R/100)^n
(1 + R/100)^n = A/P
n = log(A/P) / log(1 + R/100)

(Usually not asked directly in SSC GD; options can be tried)

Example: Try and check method
â‚¹5000 becomes â‚¹6050 at 10% CI. Find time.

Try n = 1: A = 5000(1.1) = 5500 âœ—
Try n = 2: A = 5000(1.21) = 6050 âœ“

Time = 2 years

Population Growth Problems:

Population problems use CI formula:
Final Population = Initial Ã— (1 + R/100)^n (for increase)
Final Population = Initial Ã— (1 - R/100)^n (for decrease)

Example 1: Population of a town is 10,000. If it increases by 10% per year, what will be population after 2 years?

Solution:
Initial = 10,000
Growth rate = 10% p.a.
n = 2 years

Final = 10000(1 + 10/100)Â²
      = 10000(1.1)Â²
      = 10000 Ã— 1.21
      = 12,100

Example 2: Population decreases from 10,000 to 8,100 in 2 years. Find rate of decrease.

Solution:
8100 = 10000(1 - R/100)Â²
0.81 = (1 - R/100)Â²
0.9 = 1 - R/100
R/100 = 0.1
R = 10% (decrease)

Depreciation Problems:

Depreciation also uses CI formula:
Value after n years = Initial Value Ã— (1 - R/100)^n

Example: A machine costs â‚¹100,000. If it depreciates at 10% per year, find value after 2 years.

Solution:
Value = 100000(1 - 10/100)Â²
      = 100000(0.9)Â²
      = 100000 Ã— 0.81
      = â‚¹81,000

Difference Between CI and SI:

For 2 years:
CI - SI = P(R/100)Â²

Example: Difference between CI and SI on â‚¹10,000 at 10% for 2 years.

Difference = 10000(10/100)Â²
           = 10000 Ã— 0.01
           = â‚¹100

Reverse: If difference is given, find P:
P = (Difference Ã— 10000)/RÂ²

Example: Difference is â‚¹40, Rate = 10%, find P.

P = (40 Ã— 10000)/100
  = 400000/100
  = â‚¹4000

For 3 years:
CI - SI = [PRÂ²(300 + R)]/1000000

This is more complex; usually not directly asked.

Semi-annual Problems:

Example: â‚¹10,000 at 10% p.a. for 1 year, compounded half-yearly. Find CI.

Solution:
Rate per half-year = 10/2 = 5%
Periods = 1 Ã— 2 = 2

A = 10000(1 + 5/100)Â²
  = 10000(1.05)Â²
  = 10000 Ã— 1.1025
  = â‚¹11,025

CI = 11025 - 10000 = â‚¹1025

Compare with annual:
CI = 10000(1.1) - 10000 = 1000

Extra interest = 1025 - 1000 = â‚¹25

Quarterly Problems:

Example: â‚¹8000 at 20% p.a. for 6 months, compounded quarterly.

Solution:
Rate per quarter = 20/4 = 5%
Periods = 0.5 Ã— 4 = 2

A = 8000(1.05)Â²
  = 8000 Ã— 1.1025
  = â‚¹8820

CI = 8820 - 8000 = â‚¹820

When Rates Change:

Example: â‚¹10,000 at 10% for first year and 12% for second year (CI).

Solution:
After Year 1:
Aâ‚ = 10000(1.1) = â‚¹11,000

After Year 2:
Aâ‚‚ = 11000(1.12) = â‚¹12,320

CI = 12320 - 10000 = â‚¹2320

Alternatively:
A = P(1 + Râ‚/100)(1 + Râ‚‚/100)
  = 10000(1.1)(1.12)
  = â‚¹12,320

Equivalent Rate:

Example: What single rate is equivalent to 10% for first year and 12% for second?

Solution:
Let equivalent rate = R
(1 + R/100)Â² = (1.1)(1.12)
(1 + R/100)Â² = 1.232
1 + R/100 = âˆš1.232 = 1.11 (approx)
R/100 = 0.11

slides.title: Interest - Special Formulas and Shortcuts
slides.content:
Quick formulas and shortcuts to solve interest problems faster in exams.

Simple Interest Shortcuts:

1. Doubling Time (SI):
If amount becomes double:
A = 2P, so SI = P
P = PRT/100
T = 100/R (when A = 2P)

Example: At 5% SI, time to double = 100/5 = 20 years

2. Tripling Time (SI):
A = 3P, so SI = 2P
2P = PRT/100
T = 200/R (when A = 3P)

Example: At 10% SI, time to triple = 200/10 = 20 years

3. Becoming n times (SI):
T = [(n-1) Ã— 100]/R

Example: At 5%, to become 4 times:
T = (3 Ã— 100)/5 = 60 years

4. Equal SI from Two Sums:
If Pâ‚ at Râ‚% for Tâ‚ = Pâ‚‚ at Râ‚‚% for Tâ‚‚
Then: Pâ‚Râ‚Tâ‚ = Pâ‚‚Râ‚‚Tâ‚‚

5. SI Ratio:
For same P and T at different rates:
SIâ‚ : SIâ‚‚ = Râ‚ : Râ‚‚

For same P and R at different times:
SIâ‚ : SIâ‚‚ = Tâ‚ : Tâ‚‚

Compound Interest Shortcuts:

1. CI for 2 years:
CI = P[(R/100)(2 + R/100)]

Example: P = 5000, R = 10%
CI = 5000[(10/100)(2 + 10/100)]
   = 5000[0.1 Ã— 2.1]
   = 5000 Ã— 0.21
   = â‚¹1050

2. CI - SI for 2 years:
Difference = P(R/100)Â²

Example: P = 10000, R = 10%
Difference = 10000 Ã— 0.01 = â‚¹100

3. CI for 3 years:
CI = P[(R/100)(3 + 3R/100 + RÂ²/10000)]

(This is complex; better to use A = P(1+R/100)Â³)

4. Approximate CI (for small R and T):
CI â‰ˆ P Ã— R Ã— T / 100 (like SI, but slightly more)

This works when R and T are small.

5. Rate from doubling time (CI):
If doubles in n years:
2 = (1 + R/100)^n

For specific n:
n = 2: R â‰ˆ 41.4%
n = 3: R â‰ˆ 26%
n = 5: R â‰ˆ 14.9%
n = 10: R â‰ˆ 7.2%

(These are approximations)

Rule of 72 (Doubling Time CI):

Approximate formula:
Doubling Time â‰ˆ 72/R (in years)

Example: At 8% CI, doubling time â‰ˆ 72/8 = 9 years

(Exact: 2 = 1.08^n, solving gives n â‰ˆ 9.01 years)

Rule of 114 (Tripling Time CI):

Approximate formula:
Tripling Time â‰ˆ 114/R (in years)

Example: At 12% CI, tripling time â‰ˆ 114/12 = 9.5 years

Mixed Problems Shortcuts:

1. If SI for 2 years = SI for 1 year:
Then SI per year is constant
Use SI = PRT/100

2. If CI for 2 years - SI for 2 years = x:
P = (x Ã— 10000)/RÂ²

Example: Difference = 40, R = 10%
P = (40 Ã— 10000)/100 = â‚¹4000

3. Installment Formula (approximate for SI):
Installment = P(1 + RT/100)/n

where n = number of installments

4. Present Worth (SI):
PW = A/(1 + RT/100)

Example: Find PW of â‚¹1200 due in 2 years at 10% SI.
PW = 1200/(1 + 0.2) = 1200/1.2 = â‚¹1000

5. True Discount:
TD = (A Ã— R Ã— T)/(100 + RT)

where A = Amount (future value)

Example: TD on â‚¹1100 due in 1 year at 10% SI.
TD = (1100 Ã— 10 Ã— 1)/(100 + 10)
   = 11000/110 = â‚¹100

Quick Calculations:

1. 10% of any number:
Move decimal one place left
10% of 5000 = 500

2. 5% of any number:
Half of 10%
5% of 5000 = 250

3. 20% of any number:
Double of 10%
20% of 5000 = 1000

4. 1% of any number:
Move decimal two places left
1% of 5000 = 50

5. Powers to remember:
1.05Â² = 1.1025
1.1Â² = 1.21
1.1Â³ = 1.331
1.1â´ = 1.4641
1.15Â² = 1.3225

Comparing SI and CI:

For T = 1 year: SI = CI always
For T = 2 years: CI - SI = P(R/100)Â²
For T > 1 year: CI > SI always
For T < 1 year: Calculate normally

Population/Depreciation:

Increase: Final = Initial(1 + R/100)^n
Decrease: Final = Initial(1 - R/100)^n

Net change formula:
If increases by x% and decreases by y%:
Net = x - y - (xy/100)

Example: Population increases 10%, then decreases 10%.
Net = 10 - 10 - (10Ã—10/100) = -1%
(Net decrease of 1%)

Compound Depreciation:

Example: â‚¹10,000 depreciates 10% p.a. for 2 years.
Value = 10000(0.9)Â² = 10000 Ã— 0.81 = â‚¹8100
Depreciation = 10000 - 8100 = â‚¹1900

Q1. Find SI on â‚¹6000 at 9% p.a. for 4 years.

SI = (6000 Ã— 9 Ã— 4)/100 = 216000/100 = â‚¹2160

Q2. At what rate will â‚¹8000 amount to â‚¹9600 in 2 years at SI?

Solution:
A = 9600, P = 8000, T = 2
SI = 9600 - 8000 = 1600
R = (SI Ã— 100)/(P Ã— T)
  = (1600 Ã— 100)/(8000 Ã— 2)
  = 160000/16000 = 10% p.a.

Q3. In how many years will â‚¹5000 become â‚¹6500 at 10% SI?

Solution:
SI = 6500 - 5000 = 1500
T = (SI Ã— 100)/(P Ã— R)
  = (1500 Ã— 100)/(5000 Ã— 10)
  = 150000/50000 = 3 years

Q4. Sum becomes double in 8 years at SI. Find rate.

CI:

Key Takeaways:

1. SI is straightforward: PRT/100

slides.title: Common Mistakes and Tips
slides.content:
Learn from common errors and master interest problems for SSC GD exam.

Top 10 Common Mistakes:

1. Confusing SI with CI

Mistake: Using SI = PRT/100 for CI problem

Correct:
- SI: Interest on principal only
- CI: Interest on principal + accumulated interest
- Use A = P(1+R/100)^n for CI

Example:
Wrong: CI on â‚¹1000 at 10% for 2 years = (1000Ã—10Ã—2)/100 = 200
Right: A = 1000(1.1)Â² = 1210, CI = 210

2. Not Converting Time to Years

Mistake: Using T = 6 months directly in formula

Correct:
Months â†’ Years: Divide by 12
Days â†’ Years: Divide by 365

Example:
6 months = 6/12 = 0.5 years
73 days = 73/365 = 0.2 years

3. Wrong Compounding Adjustment

Mistake: Using R and n as-is for semi-annual/quarterly

Correct:
Semi-annual: R/2 and 2n
Quarterly: R/4 and 4n
Monthly: R/12 and 12n

Example: 10% for 2 years, semi-annual
Wrong: (1.1)Â²
Right: (1.05)â´ = 1.2155

Wait, for 2 years semi-annual:
n = 2 years Ã— 2 = 4 periods
R per period = 10/2 = 5%
Correct: (1.05)â´ âœ“

4. Calculating CI as Amount

Mistake: Giving Amount as CI

Correct:
CI = Amount - Principal
Always subtract P from A

Example:
P = 1000, A = 1210
Wrong answer: â‚¹1210 (this is Amount)
Right answer: CI = 1210 - 1000 = â‚¹210

5. Wrong Power Calculation

Mistake: (1.1)Â² = 1.2 instead of 1.21

Correct:
Practice common powers:
1.05Â² = 1.1025
1.1Â² = 1.21
1.1Â³ = 1.331
1.15Â² = 1.3225

Double-check calculations!

6. Forgetting to Divide by 100

Mistake: SI = PRT (forgetting /100)

Correct:
SI = (P Ã— R Ã— T)/100

Example:
P = 5000, R = 10, T = 2
Wrong: SI = 5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2 = 100,000
Right: SI = (5000 Ã— 10 Ã— 2)/100 = 1000

7. Using Wrong Formula for CI-SI Difference

Mistake: Calculating both separately when not needed

Correct:
For 2 years: Difference = P(R/100)Â²

This is much faster!

Example: P = 10000, R = 10%
Direct: Diff = 10000(0.1)Â² = 100
Vs calculating SI = 2000, CI = 2100, then 2100-2000 = 100

8. Decimal Point Errors

Mistake: 10% = 10 instead of 0.1

Correct:
When using decimal:
10% = 10/100 = 0.1
5% = 0.05
15% = 0.15

Or always use R/100 in formula

9. Wrong Understanding of "Becomes"

Mistake: "Becomes â‚¹1200" means SI = 1200

Correct:
"Becomes" means Amount = 1200
Interest = Amount - Principal

Example: â‚¹1000 becomes â‚¹1200
SI or CI = 1200 - 1000 = 200 (not 1200!)

10. Population Increase/Decrease Confusion

Mistake: Using + for decrease

Correct:
Increase: (1 + R/100)^n

Example: 10% decrease
Wrong: (1 + 0.1) = 1.1
Right: (1 - 0.1) = 0.9

Exam Tips:

1. Read Carefully:
- Is it SI or CI?
